channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Who is Cassie? The stalled music career of the Sean Combs trial's star witness
item.description: The mogul's former protégé and girlfriend emerged as a promising pop artist in 2006. On the stand this week, she said her relationship with Combs and his label quickly became more about control.

item.title: Addiction programs that helped drug deaths plummet in 2024 now face Trump cuts
item.description: Overdose deaths plummeted in the U.S. in 2024, down by 27%. The news comes as the White House and Congress are advocating for steep cuts in programs that may be working to lower the death rate.

item.title: Medicaid recipients in key California GOP district express concerns
item.description: Lawmakers like California GOP Rep. David Valadao could be instrumental in determining the future of Medicaid. Much of his largely rural district relies on the program to pay for medical expenses.

item.title: Trump revives his Gaza proposal on his Middle East trip
item.description: President Trump hasn't talked about the war in Gaza much since landing in the Middle East. But on Thursday, he doubled down on his plan to develop it as a "freedom zone."

item.title: This week in science: biker safety, orange cats and a gum disease-heart rhythm link
item.description: Emily Kwong and Regina Barber of Short Wave talk about a tool to increase biker safety, the genetic secrets that make orange cats orange, and a link between gum disease and heart rhythm disorders.

item.title: Why top tech CEOs joined Trump on his trip to Saudi Arabia
item.description: Several major tech CEOs joined President Trump on his trip to Saudi Arabia this week. It's part of a thaw in the once-strained relationship between Big Tech and the oil-rich state.

item.title: After voters legalized abortion, Missouri Republicans put a repeal back on the ballot
item.description: Missouri Republicans are trying to repeal the right to abortion in the state by asking voters to counteract a measure they approved on the ballot last year to legalize it.

item.title: The U.S. is working on a new plan to deliver aid in Gaza
item.description: Israel has blocked the entry of aid for weeks, accusing Hamas of theft. The U.S. says its plan will address Israel's concerns. Experts say it may change humanitarian responses in conflict zones.

item.title: International musicians rethink touring the U.S. amid aggressive immigration policies
item.description: In a time of aggressive immigration enforcement, some international musicians are reconsidering the benefits of touring in the U.S.

item.title: In 'Overcompensating,' Benito Skinner turns old wounds into comedy
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Benito Skinner about his new show, Overcompensating, out on Amazon Prime on May 15.
